{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3559852,"name":"Isaac Proctor","username":"Isaac-The-Pro","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/isaac-the-pro/{size}/265401_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T22:23:05.071Z","cooked":"

We’ve been trying to lighten custom CNC’d parts by pocketing halfway through the material, but can’t seem to get it to work properly. We use Autodesk Fusion to make gcode, And when pocketing all the way through it works fine, but it cuts almost all the way through the material when we try to have it go only halfway, which defeats the purpose entirely. We’ve ran simulations and there aren’t any issues we can see, and we did small polycarb test strips with a small lighten pattern and they work just fine. Any ideas on what could be causing this issue? Any help would be appreciated.

What material are you trying to pocket?
Workholding could come into play as the traditional router bits are up cut bits.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T22:26:42.077Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":448,"readers_count":447,"score":99.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"tim-tim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559856,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T22:26:43.631Z","cooked":"

Are you getting the correct work offset and tool lengths?

If you aren’t getting a good zero, it would be easy to be consistent in cutting all the way through and only be noticeably off when cutting partway.

Polycarbonate

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T22:38:00.107Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":398,"readers_count":397,"score":84.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"Isaac Proctor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"reply_to_user":{"id":8037,"username":"tim-tim","name":"tim-tim","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tim-tim/{size}/2691_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69147,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6352 Scouting/Design Lead"},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/4","custom_user_title":"6352 Scouting/Design Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559893,"name":"tim-tim","username":"tim-tim","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tim-tim/{size}/2691_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T23:05:05.636Z","cooked":"

As the sheet size gets larger in footprint, the amount of flex/bending will likely increase, so this may be why the pocket appeared to be ok for the small test piece.
It may be worth inserting a pause in the program to allow you to add additional screws to hold the material down (assuming a spoil board/your router setup allows this) - or even split this into 2 jobs entirely allowing you to add the screws and then doing the pocketing and outer contouring.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T23:05:05.636Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":365,"readers_count":364,"score":73.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"tim-tim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":69147,"username":"Isaac-The-Pro","name":"Isaac Proctor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/isaac-the-pro/{size}/265401_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560126,"name":"FrankJ","username":"FrankJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/frankj/{size}/5392_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T03:00:06.979Z","cooked":"

Be sure the poly is the thickness you think it is. Sometimes the nominal and actual dimensions are different. Single fluke tools are hard to zero. Make sure you are not setting the zero to deep. Use material to leave setting to take off less material.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T15:17:41.313Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":123.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"FrankJ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15944,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2974 Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/6","custom_user_title":"2974 Robot Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560663,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T15:49:56.640Z","cooked":"

Assuming this is on a router:

Where are you zeroing and how beat up is the waste board?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T15:49:56.640Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":266,"readers_count":265,"score":58.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/7","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560672,"name":"Chase Vendrillo","username":"Chase1699","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chase1699/{size}/230099_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T15:57:59.528Z","cooked":"

It’s hard to diagnose the problem with the information given. For the short term, split the lighten cut and through cut into different files. For the lighten cut lie to the machine and pocket half the material depth for only the lighten paths, for the next cut do the file for the through cuts without the lighten paths. I’d be sure to do the lighten first so the part stays in place and you can use the same zero. Given the fact the smaller cuts work it very possibly is not a g-code problem and I’d look at the recommendations above.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T15:59:40.596Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":246,"readers_count":245,"score":64.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"Chase Vendrillo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1699 Captain"},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/8","custom_user_title":"1699 Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560914,"name":"Isaac Proctor","username":"Isaac-The-Pro","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/isaac-the-pro/{size}/265401_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T18:57:58.880Z","cooked":"

We are using an engraver, and we zero it right on the top of the stock, usually on the front left side of the stock. The waste board is pretty beat up(there are cuts on it that look to be from last year’s designs).

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T18:59:19.558Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":208,"readers_count":207,"score":41.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"Isaac Proctor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69147,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6352 Scouting/Design Lead"},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/9","custom_user_title":"6352 Scouting/Design Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560922,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T19:01:51.578Z","cooked":"

Between the tool forces lifting material up and the bed/spoil board not being flat I am not surprised that you’re seeing pockets that are too deep.

You might consider routing the parts from two layers of 1/8in material instead of 1/4.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T19:01:51.578Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":190,"readers_count":189,"score":58.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3561043,"name":"","username":"Rockroyal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/71c47a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T20:14:46.136Z","cooked":"

We have encountered this issue due to zeroing Z too low and having an uneven waste board. I would be surprised if those two aren’t the root cause of this, given what you said about the simulations looking good.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T20:14:46.136Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":35.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54047,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3561091,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T20:53:24.192Z","cooked":"

Very underrated way to make 2.5D parts.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T20:53:24.192Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":161,"readers_count":160,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3782,"username":"JamesCH95","name":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/12","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3561359,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T01:40:31.364Z","cooked":"

Get one or two of these.

amazon.com

CNC Spoilboard Surfacing Router Bits, 1/2 inch Shank 2 inch Cutting Diameter,...

NITOMAK T-moulding 1/2-Inch Shank CNC Spoilboard Surfacing Router Bit (3 Wings) for Craftsman✔Designed for desktop engraving machines (such as CNC hand-held and table-mounted router), it can not be used in electric drill & drill machines.✔Exquisite...

$17.77

Resurface your spoil board immediately after installing it and after every 10-20 jobs or before critical ones. Knocking off .01 is all it takes after the first dress-in.

Here’s a dumb question, perhaps. How do you resurface your entire spoil board while still clamping it to the router? Or should we assume that it is heavy enough not to move when being surfaced?

Our spoilboard is mounted with t-nuts on top of an 80/20 grid so it doesn’t move. We usually only face it once or twice a year though

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T06:13:18.754Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":101,"readers_count":100,"score":35.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495965,"topic_slug":"issues-machining-lightened-parts","display_username":"Ryan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":15481,"username":"MysterE","name":"MysterE","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mystere/{size}/121596_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74233,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/issues-machining-lightened-parts/495965/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3561499,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T07:08:06.848Z","cooked":"

Counterbored mounting holes in the MDF spoilboard, with brass fasteners attaching it to the tslots so if you hit one it’s not a huge problem.

About 1/2" counterbore in a 3/4" MDF spoilboard has worked well for us.

We make the counterbore big enough to fit a standard washer under the hex head of the bolt, something like 7/8" OD

I use recessed brass screws to mount my spoil board. Even if I do clip a screw it isn’t a big deal, but I haven’t clipped a screw resurfacing.

1 flute up cut end mills tend to lift poly carb. Use more fasteners to hold it down. Our router has a combo presser foot and dust collector. It solves the lifting problem and is very good at sucking up the cuttings.
